entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Secure Payment Confirmation: UX Refresh
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Secure Payment Confirmation: UX Refresh
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+Secure+Payment+Confirmation%5C%3A+UX+Refresh%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: Secure Payment Confirmation: UX Refresh</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250603" rel="nofollow">Tue, 03 Jun 2025 13:43:08 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails darwiny...@chromium.org, slobo...@chromium.org, smcgr...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/197</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/275</a>
Specification None
Summary
Updates the UX elements for the SPC dialog on Android Chrome. Other than just UX presentation the following are being added: - Allowing merchants to provide an optional list of payment entity logos related to the payment that will be displayed in the UX (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/294</a>). - Returning different output states back to the merchant depending on whether the user wants to continue the transaction without SPC or to cancel the transaction (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/292</a>). Currently, we only send a single output state back for both cases. - A new payment detail label field will be added to the payment instrument so the text be presented across 2 lines in SPC (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/298</a>)
Blink component Blink>Payments
Motivation
Updating the UX for SPC on Android Chrome helps users navigate and understand the dialog and provides more signal back to merchants on user intents.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/2025/04/24-wpwg-minutes.html#8400">https://www.w3.org/2025/04/24-wpwg-minutes.html#8400</a>
TAG review None
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? No
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification None
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/405173922">https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/405173922</a>
Launch bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4397413">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4397413</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on Android 139

This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.

</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] RE: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support width and height as presentation attributes on nested <svg> elements
entry.summary: [blink-dev] RE: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support width and height as presentation attributes on nested <svg> elements
entry.content:
<div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hi Dominic, thanks for your suggestions in the I2S As suggested, our current action involves writing WPTs to better understand the expected behavior of missing CSS values. This will enable us to present more informed and concrete results to the CSSWG and other platforms, fostering clearer discussions and more consistent implementations.</pre><pre>
We will update the I2S once that step that done.
From: Domenic Denicola <dome...@chromium.org> Sent: Friday, June 13, 2025 7:33 AM To: blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org> Cc: Divyansh Mangal <dman...@microsoft.com> Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: Intent to Ship: Support width and height as presentation attributes on nested <svg> elements
This intent feels a little risky, because, as WebKit points out<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/509">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/509</a>> in their standards-positions issue, there isn't really an adequate specification for how SVG layout works in cases like this. For example, how it will behave with non-px values. (The WPTs you link only include px values.)
Since SVG2 is a mostly-unmaintained specification, and this feature has at least some web developer demand, I don't want to require that you specify everything perfectly here. But I'd like to see at least some of:
* Discussion with other implementers in the standards positions issues. (You've started these discussions, but I'd like to give them more time to settle.) * More exhaustive web platform test coverage, including values like `min-content`, `calc-size()`, `20em`, `50%`, `auto`, `stretch`, `50vh`, etc. * Some discussion in the CSSWG about how they would like to see this specified in the future. * A pull request to update the relevant parts of the SVG2 spec with some vague language about the expected results; it doesn't have to be rigorous, but it should be at least enough for other implementers to understand how to follow our behavior. Not all of these are required, and if I had to pick a single one that was most important, it would be expanded web platform test coverage.
On Wednesday, June 11, 2025 at 10:28:17 PM UTC+9 dma...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:dma...@microsoft.com">mailto:dma...@microsoft.com</a>> wrote:
Contact emails
dman...@microsoft.com<<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:dman...@microsoft.com">mailto:dman...@microsoft.com</a>>
Explainer
None
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/geometry.html#Sizing">https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/geometry.html#Sizing</a>
Summary
This feature supports applying width and height as presentation attributes on nested <svg> elements through both SVG markup and CSS. This dual approach provides even greater flexibility for developers, allowing them to manage and style SVG elements more efficiently within complex designs.
With this feature the below two html will now have the same output:
With CSS Properties for nested <svg> element:
<svg width="100px" height="100px">
<svg style="width:50px;height:50px;">
<circle cx="50px" cy="50px" r="40px" fill="green" />
</svg>
</svg>
Without CSS Properties for nested <svg> element:
<svg width="100px" height="100px">
<svg width="50px" height="50px">
<circle cx="50px" cy="50px" r="40px" fill="green" />
</svg>
</svg>
Blink component
Blink>SVG<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESVG%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESVG%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1243">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1243</a>) In Firefox, the width and height attributes cannot be applied on nested <svg> elements as styles
WebKit: Neutral (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/509">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/509</a>) In Safari, the width and height attributes cannot be applied on nested <svg> elements as styles
Web developers: Positive 7 people have upvoted this in the chromium issue.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
Existing Devtools capabilities already support this feature.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
WPTs in chromium: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/styling/nested-svg-sizing.svg">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/styling/nested-svg-sizing.svg</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/styling/nested-svg-sizing-with-use.svg">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/styling/nested-svg-sizing-with-use.svg</a>
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
WidthAndHeightAsPresentationAttributesOnNestedSvg
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40409865">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40409865</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
139
Shipping on Android
139
Shipping on WebView
139
Shipping on iOS
139
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None

-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/KUXP153MB1324A60C07A308B04C8BAB4AAD77A%40KUXP153MB1324.APCP153.PROD.OUTLOOK.COM">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/KUXP153MB1324A60C07A308B04C8BAB4AAD77A%40KUXP153MB1324.APCP153.PROD.OUTLOOK.COM</a>. </pre>

<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+counter%5C%28%5C%29+and+counters%5C%28%5C%29+in+alt+text+of+%27content%27+property%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniil+Sakhapov%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniil Sakhapov</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250616" rel="nofollow">Mon, 16 Jun 2025 07:43:59 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailssakha...@chromium.org
ExplainerNone</pre><pre>
Specification<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property</a>
Summary
counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property is useful to provide more meaningful information to e.g. pseudo elements to improve their accessibility.

entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Script Blocking in Incognito
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Script+Blocking+in+Incognito%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Script Blocking in Incognito</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Zainab+Rizvi%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Zainab Rizvi' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250616" rel="nofollow">Mon, 16 Jun 2025 07:24:51 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emailsriz...@google.com, mk...@chromium.org
Explainer<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/script-blocking">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/script-blocking</a></pre><pre>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/script-blocking/blob/main/index.bs">https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/script-blocking/blob/main/index.bs</a>
Summary
Mitigating API Misuse for Browser Re-Identification, otherwise known as Script Blocking is a feature that will block scripts engaging in known, prevalent techniques for browser re-identification in third-party contexts. These techniques typically involve the misuse of existing browser APIs to extract additional information about the user's browser or device characteristics.
To strike this balance between protection and usability, this proposal focuses on blocking scripts in a third-party context in Incognito mode. This proposal uses a list-based approach, where only domains marked as “Impacted by Script Blocking” on the Masked Domain List (MDL) <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/GoogleChrome/ip-protection/blob/main/Masked-Domain-List.md">https://github.com/GoogleChrome/ip-protection/blob/main/Masked-Domain-List.md</a>> in a third-party context will be impacted.
When the feature is enabled, Chrome will check network requests against the blocklist. This feature will reuse Chromium's subresource_filter component, which is responsible for tagging and filtering subresource requests based on page-level activation signals and a ruleset used to match URLs for filtering.
Blink componentBlink>Network>FetchAPI <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EFetchAPI%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EFetchAPI%22</a>>
TAG review<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1114">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1114</a>
TAG review statusPending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
There shouldn’t be any interop concerns. In terms of compatibility, this feature is anticipated to have an impact on websites that rely on scripts from domains identified as serving fingerprinting techniques. Sites that integrate third-party scripts from identified domains may experience functional breakage or render incorrectly when accessed in Incognito mode.
*Gecko*: Shipped/Shipping ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/trackers-and-scripts-firefox-blocks-enhanced-track">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/trackers-and-scripts-firefox-blocks-enhanced-track</a> )
*WebKit*: Shipped/Shipping ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://webkit.org/tracking-prevention/#private-browsing-mode">https://webkit.org/tracking-prevention/#private-browsing-mode</a>)
*Web developers*: No signals
*Other signals*:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Goals for experimentation
We will run a 1% stable experiment for users when in Incognito mode. Our motivation is functional in nature: we would like to better understand the breakage impact on sites, performance impact of checking requests against a blocklist, as well as testing that updates to the MDL, such as domain additions and removals (from changes to Disconnect's source lists or successful appeals) propagate to Chrome clients.
We will consider site breakage rates (indicated via user reports, aggregated UMA logging) as well as performance metrics (e.g., page load time, memory usage).
Ongoing technical constraints
None
Debuggability
We have added support in DevTools Issues to indicate which requests are being blocked by this feature. We also have chrome://flags/##enable-fingerprinting-protection-blocklist-incognito which developers and users can use for testing suspected breakage.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?No
We plan to launch this on all Blink platforms except WebView.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?No
We are exploring ways to test this feature via WPT. We want to test the correct integration and ordering of the script blocking mechanism within the Fetch API.
Flag name on about://flagsEnable Fingerprinting Protection Blocklist In Incognito
Finch feature nameEnableFingerprintingProtectionInIncognito
Requires code in //chrome?True
Tracking bug<a rel="nofollow" href="https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/411138638">https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/411138638</a>
Launch bug<a rel="nofollow" href="https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4367306">https://launch.corp.google.com/launch/4367306</a>
Estimated milestones
We would like to run the experiment from M137 to M142 inclusive.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5188989497376768?gate=5165545720381440">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5188989497376768?gate=5165545720381440</a>
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAFhOYsgKDRo%3D0g%2BtJpej_ET0_2Ed20B407myiu%3D%2BicVnB7JboQ%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAFhOYsgKDRo%3D0g%2BtJpej_ET0_2Ed20B407myiu%3D%2BicVnB7JboQ%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS typed arithmetic
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS typed arithmetic
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+typed+arithmetic%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS typed arithmetic</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250616" rel="nofollow">Mon, 16 Jun 2025 05:13:12 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails sakha...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#calc-type-checking">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#calc-type-checking</a>
Summary
Typed arithmetic allows to write expressions in CSS such a calc(10em / 1px) or calc(20% / 0.5em * 1px) which is useful for eg typography, as it allows to convert typed value into an untyped one and reuse it for number accepting properties or futher multiply the unitless value by some other type to eg cast from pixels to degrees.
Blink component Blink>CSS
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1252">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1252</a>)
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping
Web developers: Strongly positive Verbal confirmation from multiple developers that they really need it
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/getComputedStyle-calc-mixed-units-003.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/getComputedStyle-calc-mixed-units-003.html</a>
Flag name on about://flags CSSTypedArithmetic
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification None
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40768696">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40768696</a>
Estimated milestones
DevTrial on desktop 138
DevTrial on Android 138
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4740780497043456?gate=5654265095520256">https://chromestatus.com/feature/4740780497043456?gate=5654265095520256</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: CSS border-shape
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: CSS border-shape
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Prototype%5C%3A+CSS+border%5C-shape%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Prototype: CSS border-shape</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250617" rel="nofollow">Tue, 17 Jun 2025 03:59:13 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails nrosent...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/noamr/explainers/blob/main/border-shape-explainer.md">https://github.com/noamr/explainers/blob/main/border-shape-explainer.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-borders-4/#border-shape">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-borders-4/#border-shape</a>
Summary
CSS border-shape enables creating non-rectangular borders, with any arbitrary shape (polygon, circle, shape(), etc). Though border-shape accepts the same shapes as clip-path, it is fundamentally different: border-shape defines the shape of the border, decorates it, and clips only the inside. border-shape has two variants: one variant that strokes a shape, and another variant that fills between two shapes.
Blink component Blink>CSS
Motivation
Together with shape() and corner-shape, border-shape allows authoring non-box designs in the web, enabling a more expressive and beautiful web. It addresses an old limitation where clipping is free-form but borders are rectangular.
Initial public proposal <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-borders-4/#border-shape">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-borders-4/#border-shape</a>
TAG review None
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal
WebKit: No signal
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes
Flag name on about://flags CSSBorderShape
Finch feature name CSSBorderShape
Requires code in //chrome? False
Estimated milestones
No milestones specified
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5459864205393920?gate=5070207189778432">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5459864205393920?gate=5070207189778432</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Crash Reporting API: Specify crash-reporting to receive only crash reports
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Crash Reporting API: Specify crash-reporting to receive only crash reports
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Crash+Reporting+API%5C%3A+Specify+crash%5C-reporting+to+receive+only+crash+reports%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Crash Reporting API: Specify crash-reporting to receive only crash reports</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250618" rel="nofollow">Wed, 18 Jun 2025 08:19:20 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-06-18 17:16, Mike Taylor wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM2
On 6/18/25 10:58 AM, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1
On Monday, June 16, 2025 at 6:25:02 AM UTC+2 Chromestatus wrote:
Contact emails
zhoupeng.1...@bytedance.com
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263">https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263">https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/issues/24">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/issues/24</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/issues/24">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/issues/24</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30</a>>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority">https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority">https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority</a>>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30">https://github.com/WICG/crash-reporting/pull/30</a>>
Summary
This feature ensures developers receive only crash reports by specifying the endpoint named `crash-reporting `. By default, crash reports are delivered to the `default` endpoint which receives many other kinds of reports besides crash reports. Developers can supply a separate URL to the well-known endpoint named `crash-reporting`, to direct crash reports there, instead of the `default` endpoint. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority">https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority">https://wicg.github.io/crash-reporting/#crash-reports-delivery-priority</a>>.
Blink component
Blink <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%22</a>>
TAG review
As this feature is a trivial API addition with no impact on default behavior, the TAG Specification Review is unnecessary.
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
/Gecko/: Positive
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/288#issuecomment-2944953563">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/288#issuecomment-2944953563</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/288#issuecomment-2944953563">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/288#issuecomment-2944953563</a>>)
/WebKit/: No signal
(<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/456#issuecomment-2944940233">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/456#issuecomment-2944940233</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/456#issuecomment-2944940233">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/456#issuecomment-2944940233</a>>)
/Web developers/: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263">https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263">https://github.com/w3c/reporting/issues/263</a>>)
/Other signals/:
Security
This feature only adds a way to report crash reports exclusively. Therefore, we believe there are no security concerns.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
No
There are no web platform tests for this tiny addition to the crash reporting API, because the crash reporting API itself cannot be tested this way at the moment. WPTs do not support crashing the renderer process for a contrived set of reasons (OOM, unresponsiveness, etc). Note that this has been documented in all of the other parts of this API that have shipped. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/tgRcEnqIb1A">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/tgRcEnqIb1A</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/tgRcEnqIb1A">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/tgRcEnqIb1A</a>>, for example.
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
OverrideCrashReportingEndpoint
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/414723480">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/414723480</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/414723480">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/414723480</a>>

Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. None

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Re-Sizing TCP Connection Pool
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Re-Sizing TCP Connection Pool
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Experiment%5C%3A+Re%5C-Sizing+TCP+Connection+Pool%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Experiment: Re-Sizing TCP Connection Pool</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Ari+Chivukula%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Ari Chivukula</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250618" rel="nofollow">Wed, 18 Jun 2025 08:18:39 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
aric...@chromium.org, awil...@chromium.org, a...@google.com, miketa...@chromium.org Explainer</pre><pre>
None Specification
Not yet
Summary
This experiment evaluates the impact of changing the per-profile TCP socket pool size from 256 (the current default <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:net/socket/client_socket_pool_manager.cc;drc=8b81608b6457dfef865f46e509c79dc60fe3c69b;l=35">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:net/socket/client_socket_pool_manager.cc;drc=8b81608b6457dfef865f46e509c79dc60fe3c69b;l=35</a>>), down to 255, and up to 257, 512, and 1024 (possibly at 1-2 numbers between those based on findings). We will study the performance impact of these changes in stages, starting with 255 and 257. If no ill effects are seen, 512 will be evaluated and then 1024 after that. We expect that some platforms (e.g., mobile or older OS versions) will have to drop off as we get to the 512/1024 experiments. We will study changes to both normal and websocket pool global limits, but will not touch the per-host or per-proxy limits.
This experiment will not be rolled directly into a full launch, but rather evaluated for use in a future experiment that attempts to partition the TCP socket pool to mitigate a network traffic timing attack. See the motivation section for more.
Blink component
Blink>Network <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable at this stage, will ask for review when we have a partitioning scheme to solicit feedback on.
Motivation
Having a fixed pool of TCP sockets available to an entire profile allows attackers to effectively divinate the amount of network requests done by other tabs, and learn things about them to the extent that any given site can be profiled. For example, if a site does X network requests if it’s logged in and Y if it’s logged out, by saturating the TCP socket pool and watching movement after calling window.open, the state of the other site can be gleaned.
In order to address this sort of attack, some sort of partitioning of the TCP socket pool will be needed, but this means changing the amount of sockets available across a profile, to a given frame/tab/top-site, or both. This experiment seeks data on the feasibility of such changes so a followup experiment can be done that focuses on the impact of partitioning without also having to use it to evaluate the impact of global socket pool size changes.
This sort of attack is outlined in more detail here: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://xsleaks.dev/docs/attacks/timing-attacks/connection-pool/">https://xsleaks.dev/docs/attacks/timing-attacks/connection-pool/</a>
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
While other user agents may wish to follow the results, we only anticipate compatibility issues with local machines or remote servers when the amount of available TCP sockets in the browser fluctuates up in a way Chrome did not allow before. This will be monitored carefully, and any experiment yielding significant negative impact on browsing experience will be terminated early.
Gecko: Currently 128-900 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla-firefox/firefox/blob/4bd4e4c595499ee51c2e6f4c9f780fe720f454e8/modules/libpref/init/all.js#L1138">https://github.com/mozilla-firefox/firefox/blob/4bd4e4c595499ee51c2e6f4c9f780fe720f454e8/modules/libpref/init/all.js#L1138</a>> (as allowed by OS)
WebKit: Currently 256 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/blob/d323b2fc4cd2686c828bd8976fae6ec2d2b6311c/Source/WebCore/platform/network/soup/SoupNetworkSession.cpp#L104">https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/blob/d323b2fc4cd2686c828bd8976fae6ec2d2b6311c/Source/WebCore/platform/network/soup/SoupNetworkSession.cpp#L104</a>>
Debuggability
This will be gated behind the base::feature kTcpConnectionPoolSizeTrial, so if breakage is suspected that flag could be turned off to detect impact. For how to control feature flags, see this <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/feature_list.h;drc=159a65729cf8fca4d9f453d12d97ab6515360491;l=259">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/feature_list.h;drc=159a65729cf8fca4d9f453d12d97ab6515360491;l=259</a>> .
Measurement
Net.TcpConnectAttempt.Latency.{Result} will be used to detect increases in overall connection failure rates.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No, not WebView. That will have to be studied independently due to the differing constraints.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests?
No, as this is a blink networking focused change browser tests or unit tests are more likely.
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
kTcpConnectionPoolSizeTrial
Rollout plan
We will never test more than 1% in each group on stable, and will stay on canary/dev/beta for a while to detect issues before testing stable.
Requires code in //chrome?
No
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/415691664">https://crbug.com/415691664</a>
Estimated milestones
139
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5182293874049024">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5182293874049024</a>
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJuOcukaf_t9L7v3P8R8BpOe%3D2xY-vna369yj2gAEkgAw%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJuOcukaf_t9L7v3P8R8BpOe%3D2xY-vna369yj2gAEkgAw%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Randomizing TCP Port Allocation on Windows
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Randomizing TCP Port Allocation on Windows
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Randomizing+TCP+Port+Allocation+on+Windows%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Randomizing TCP Port Allocation on Windows</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Ari+Chivukula%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Ari Chivukula</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250618" rel="nofollow">Wed, 18 Jun 2025 08:12:30 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
aric...@chromium.org, awil...@chromium.org, miketa...@chromium.org Explainer</pre><pre>
None Specification
None
Summary
This launch enables TCP port randomization on versions of Windows (2020 H1 or later) where we do not expect to see issues with re-use of prior ports occurring too fast (causing rejection due to timeouts on port re-use). The rapid port re-use issue arises from the Birthday problem <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birthday_problem">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birthday_problem</a>>, where the probability of randomly re-picking a port already seen rapidly converges with 100% for each new port chosen when compared to port re-use in a sequential model.
Blink component
Blink>Network <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Motivation
When port randomization is disabled (the default), sites are able to count the amount of connections opened by other tabs if they check the TCP port used for new connections before and after opening another window. This knowledge can be used to glean information about other sites like whether they are logged in or not.
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This launch only impacts Windows, and should not cause compatibility issues as Microsoft backported their port randomization fix <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5464674">https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5464674</a>> to Windows 10, 2020 H1 and tested it in Edge.
Chrome previously attempted to roll this out in 2021 but ran into (since resolved) issues where rapid port re-use caused network errors.
Rollout on linux isn’t needed as port randomization is enabled by default while on macOS an issue similar to the one on Windows with rapid port re-use causing issues is still around.
Gecko: Appears to inherit OS defaults <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Amozilla-firefox%2Ffirefox+setsockopt&type=code&p=1">https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Amozilla-firefox%2Ffirefox+setsockopt&type=code&p=1</a>>
WebKit: Appears to inherit OS defaults <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AWebKit%2FWebKit+setsockopt&type=code">https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AWebKit%2FWebKit+setsockopt&type=code</a>>
Web developers: N/A
Debuggability
This will be gated behind the base::feature kTcpPortRandomizationWin, so if breakage is suspected that flag could be turned off to detect impact. For how to control feature flags, see this <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/feature_list.h;drc=159a65729cf8fca4d9f453d12d97ab6515360491;l=259">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/feature_list.h;drc=159a65729cf8fca4d9f453d12d97ab6515360491;l=259</a>> .
Measurement
The histogram Net.TCPSocket.PortReuseTimeWindows2.{IPType}.{Result} will be used to gauge whether port re-use timings fall too low, while Net.TcpConnectAttempt.Latency.{Result} will be used to detect increases in overall connection failure rates.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
No, just Windows
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests?
No, as this is a blink networking focused change browser tests or unit tests are more likely.
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
kTcpPortRandomizationWin
Rollout plan
This will be rolled out slowly to detect issues early and either change the version target or roll back. We don’t believe an experiment is needed or desired as the issues we saw before were not very prevalent, we likely need to go beyond 1% to get enough data on Windows to know if there’s still a problem.
Requires code in //chrome?
No
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/40744069">https://crbug.com/40744069</a>
Estimated milestones
139
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106900286570496">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106900286570496</a>
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJXnNbt4LMv8oD8BeRwxbD97tfCuB2o9d80_YvaDD-n1A%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAGpy5DJXnNbt4LMv8oD8BeRwxbD97tfCuB2o9d80_YvaDD-n1A%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Implement and Ship: ReadableStreamBYOBReader Min Option
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Implement and Ship: ReadableStreamBYOBReader Min Option
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Implement+and+Ship%5C%3A+ReadableStreamBYOBReader+Min+Option%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Implement and Ship: ReadableStreamBYOBReader Min Option</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250618" rel="nofollow">Wed, 18 Jun 2025 08:12:25 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3
</pre><tt>If you can improve the documentation, that would be appreciated but it's </tt><tt>not blocking anything. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
/Daniel
On 2025-06-18 17:10, Mike Taylor wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM2
On 6/12/25 9:54 PM, Domenic Denicola wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM1
On Friday, June 13, 2025 at 1:27:32 AM UTC+9 Sneha Agarwal wrote:
Contact emails snehagar...@microsoft.com, stev...@microsoft.com
Explainer None
</pre><tt>Note that the feature is somewhat documented at </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ReadableStreamBYOBReader/read">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ReadableStreamBYOBReader/read</a> </tt><tt>. A more detailed explainer with alternatives considered, etc., would </tt><tt>have been nice, but I don't think making you write one as the second </tt><tt>implementer is necessary. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>For those interested, the spec PR </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/streams/pull/1145">https://github.com/whatwg/streams/pull/1145</a>> which added this </tt><tt>contains some discussion and links to relevant issues, especially </tt><tt>this one <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/streams/issues/1175">https://github.com/whatwg/streams/issues/1175</a>>. There's a </tt><tt>lot of specification details discussion mixed in as well, but people </tt><tt>can find the design discussion too. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read">https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read">https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#byob-reader-read</a>>
Summary
This feature introduces a min option to the existing ReadableStreamBYOBReader.read(view) API. The API already accepts a ArrayBufferView into which data is read, but currently does not guarantee how many elements will be written before the read resolves. The min option is an additive, opt-in enhancement - it does not affect existing behavior for applications that don’t use it. By specifying a min value, developers can require that the stream wait until at least that many elements are available before resolving the read. This improves upon the current behavior, where reads may resolve with fewer elements than the view can hold.
Blink component Blink>Network>StreamsAPI
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EStreamsAPI%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ENetwork%3EStreamsAPI%22</a>>
Search tags streamsAPI <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:streamsAPI">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:streamsAPI</a>>, BYOB <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:BYOB">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:BYOB</a>>, ReadableStreamBYOBReader <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:ReadableStreamBYOBReader">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:ReadableStreamBYOBReader</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
/Gecko/: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1864406">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1864406</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1864406">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1864406</a>>) Feature shipped in 134
/WebKit/: No signal
</pre><tt>Note that while "No signal" is the correct way of filling out this </tt><tt>field, since there's no official standards position, we have a public </tt><tt>statement on the spec PR that "WebKit supports this addition" </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/streams/pull/1145#issuecomment-1582499354">https://github.com/whatwg/streams/pull/1145#issuecomment-1582499354</a>>. </tt><tt>Combined with the WebKit bug </tt><tt><<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=264731">https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=264731</a>> on file for </tt><tt>implementing this, I think it is reasonable to approve this without </tt><tt>requiring a formal standards position. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Web developers/: Positive Developers requested this feature in Chromium <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40942083">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40942083</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40942083">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40942083</a>> , <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/383158935">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/383158935</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/383158935">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/383158935</a>>
/Other signals/: None
WebView application risks
/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?/
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
Flag name on about://flags N/A
Finch feature name ReadableStreamBYOBReaderReadMinOption
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/0/issues/40942083?pli=1">https://issues.chromium.org/u/0/issues/40942083?pli=1</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/u/0/issues/40942083?pli=1">https://issues.chromium.org/u/0/issues/40942083?pli=1</a>>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 140 Shipping on Android 140 Shipping on WebView 140
Anticipated spec changes
/Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way)./
None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6396991665602560?gate=6377960329969664">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6396991665602560?gate=6377960329969664</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6396991665602560?gate=6377960329969664">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6396991665602560?gate=6377960329969664</a>>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Secure Payment Confirmation: Browser Bound Keys
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Secure Payment Confirmation: Browser Bound Keys
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Secure+Payment+Confirmation%5C%3A+Browser+Bound+Keys%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Secure Payment Confirmation: Browser Bound Keys</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250625" rel="nofollow">Wed, 25 Jun 2025 12:54:32 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>I am curious about this as a vector for privacy intrusion. There is </tt><tt>probably something I have missed so feel free to explain what I am missing. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>These browser bound keys are per design locked to a specific device. </tt><tt>Doesn't that mean that it allows a bad actor to keep track of a user's </tt><tt>devices, or even keep track of users, like some kind of very special </tt><tt>cookie? The explainer talks about this being used in an </tt><tt>embedded/cross-origin environment which means that avoiding tracking is </tt><tt>even more important. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>How about clearing the data, will this be deleted if a deletes "cookies" </tt><tt>or "browsing data"? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>The explainer says that a full privacy analysis should be done, but that </tt><tt>is from last spring so maybe it has been done? </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-06-25 17:03, Vladimir Levin wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> That makes sense, thank you for the answers.
LGTM2
On Wednesday, June 25, 2025 at 9:42:19 AM UTC-4 Slobodan Pejic wrote:
Hi Vladimir,
Thanks for the questions:
1. How *do* you avoid replay attacks in this case? If a device is uniquely identified by a key that is only challenged by 2FA (like SMS) on the first try, what prevents a person-in-the-middle from learning this key and using it later?
The clientDataJSON
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-authenticatorresponse-clientdatajson">https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-authenticatorresponse-clientdatajson</a>> contains a challenge <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-collectedclientdata-challenge">https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn-2/#dom-collectedclientdata-challenge</a>> field: WebAuthn passes clientDataJSON (or rather a hash of the clientDataJSON) to the authenticator for signing. The browser bound key also signs the clientDataJSON containing the challenge. On another transaction a person-in-the-middle does not have access to the browser bound private key needed to sign over the challenge. The relying party can protect against replay attacks by providing a random challenge, checking the challenge matches, and verifying the signature.
2. There is some discussion to switching to a device bound key if WebAuthn supports that. Is the possibility of shared devices considered an acceptable risk? Specifically, SMS 2FA is "your phone number" which can be reasonably thought as your and yours alone, but a device like a desktop is commonly shared device (e.g. library computer). Or is the device key something that changes based on login or some other criteria?
Browser bound keys are associated to the tuple (a passkey, a browser instance, a device) in the Chrome profile, so a separate os login would produce a different browser bound key for the same passkey, and different browser bound keys would be provided for different passkeys in the same profile. If someone is at a library computer, they first need access to the passkey before the matching browser bound key. Secure Payment Confirmation requires userVerification
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#dom-publickeycredentialrequestoptions-userverification">https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#dom-publickeycredentialrequestoptions-userverification</a>> (see SPC spec
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-steps-to-respond-to-a-payment-request">https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-steps-to-respond-to-a-payment-request</a>>) when invoking WebAuthn (e.g., on Android enter the lock screen pin/fingerprint, on MacOS provide your fingerprint), so the user must be present to use an existing passkey before the browser bound key would be used to sign the transaction. A different passkey would yield a different browser bound key; however, even if an attacker managed to use a browser bound key on the same library computer with an attacker controlled passkey, then relying parties can detect the mismatch (on top of not recognizing the attacker's passkey).
To be clear, if WebAuthn introduces a form of device-binding, Chrome will continue to provide browser bound keys (i.e., there is no code or spec to switch browser bound key provider to WebAuthn). When or if WebAuthn supports device binding we would re-evaluate the need/requirements for browser bound keys in the web payments working group.
On Tue, Jun 24, 2025 at 9:55 PM Vladimir Levin <vmp...@chromium.org> wrote:
On Tuesday, June 10, 2025 at 2:47:10 PM UTC-4 Chromestatus wrote:
Contact emails slobo...@chromium.org, smcgr...@chromium.org, rous...@chromium.org
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a>>
In the explainer you mention the following: > It is worth noting that this proposal is in some ways re-inventing the wheel of what already exists and/or will exist in WebAuthn. In particular, it means that we have to be careful to avoid all the traps/problems with signatures that WebAuthn already has solved (e.g., challenges to avoid replay attacks, choice of signing algorithms, quantum-proofing, etc). Where possible, we should look to write the spec relying on WebAuthn concepts, even if the actual key creation and storage does not use WebAuthn authenticators.
I don't follow WebAuthn progress closely, so the questions I have may be naive, but bear with with me.
1. How *do* you avoid replay attacks in this case? If a device is uniquely identified by a key that is only challenged by 2FA (like SMS) on the first try, what prevents a person-in-the-middle from learning this key and using it later?
2. There is some discussion to switching to a device bound key if WebAuthn supports that. Is the possibility of shared devices considered an acceptable risk? Specifically, SMS 2FA is "your phone number" which can be reasonably thought as your and yours alone, but a device like a desktop is commonly shared device (e.g. library computer). Or is the device key something that changes based on login or some other criteria?
Thanks! Vlad
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-browser-bound-key-store">https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-browser-bound-key-store</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-browser-bound-key-store">https://w3c.github.io/secure-payment-confirmation/#sctn-browser-bound-key-store</a>>
Design docs <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/271</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/286">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/286</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/286">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/286</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/296">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/296</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/296">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/pull/296</a>>
Summary
Adds an additional cryptographic signature over Secure Payment Confirmation assertions and credential creation. The corresponding private key is not synced across devices. This helps web developers meet requirements for device binding for payment transactions.
Blink component Blink>Payments
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EPayments%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EPayments%22</a>>
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1097">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1097</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1097">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1097</a>>
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Browser bound keys are an additive feature for Secure Payment Confirmation, the risk is that other browser do not implement it.
/Gecko/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/570</a>>) Firefox have never finalized their view on SPC, so we updated the original SPC issue with a note on this additional capability.
/WebKit/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/30</a>>) Safari have never finalized their view on SPC, so we updated the original SPC issue with a note on this additional capability.
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
Debuggability
Web developers should be able to inspect the new signature output which is defined in WebIDL, thus no changes are needed in devtools.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? No
Browser bound keys add to Secure Payment Confirmation which is supported only on Android, Windows, and Mac.
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? No
Web platform tests depend on the availability of a software implementation. Whether software implementation of BBK would be permitted is an open issue: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/288">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/288</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/288">https://github.com/w3c/secure-payment-confirmation/issues/288</a>>.
DevTrial instructions
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Wgx8MQG4GsdPErGPya7iMCbhw5NiSrLrNIoDPq2_P2s/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Wgx8MQG4GsdPErGPya7iMCbhw5NiSrLrNIoDPq2_P2s/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Wgx8MQG4GsdPErGPya7iMCbhw5NiSrLrNIoDPq2_P2s/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Wgx8MQG4GsdPErGPya7iMCbhw5NiSrLrNIoDPq2_P2s/edit?usp=sharing</a>>
Flag name on about://flags enable-secure-payment-confirmation-browser-bound-key
Finch feature name SecurePaymentConfirmationBrowserBoundKeys
Rollout plan Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/377278827">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/377278827</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/377278827">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/377278827</a>>
Measurement Browser bound keys are an additive to Secure Payment Confirmation: The Secure Payment Confirmation UseCounter will be used.
Availability expectation Secure Payment Confirmation (and Browser Bound Keys) are only in Chromium browsers for the foreseeable future.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function?
No
Sample links <a rel="nofollow" href="https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-sync">https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-sync</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-sync">https://rsolomakhin.github.io/pr/spc-sync</a>>
Estimated milestones Shipping on Android 139 DevTrial on Android 135
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).

<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106102997614592?gate=5080941065928704">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106102997614592?gate=5080941065928704</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106102997614592?gate=5080941065928704">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5106102997614592?gate=5080941065928704</a>>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+counter%5C%28%5C%29+and+counters%5C%28%5C%29+in+alt+text+of+%27content%27+property%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: CSS counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250702" rel="nofollow">Wed, 02 Jul 2025 08:44:55 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM3 (per Yoav's description)
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-07-02 17:40, Yoav Weiss (@Shopify) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 conditional on two things: 1) Removing the "at risk" label from the spec </pre><tt>2) Including an example in the spec and relevant documentation about </tt><tt>*how* developers are supposed to use this. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Specifically for (2), since the presence of `counter()` breaks the </tt><tt>"content:" property (as it's invalid syntax in non-supporting </tt><tt>browsers), we want developers that are using this to also provide a </tt><tt>`content:` property that doesn't include a `counter()` and precedes </tt><tt>the one that does. </tt><tt>This needs to be *very* clear to developers that are reaching out for </tt><tt>this tool. </tt><tt>(and right now it isn't. Jeffrey Yasskin on the API owners call </tt><tt>mentioned this is a correct fallback for developers to use) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Wednesday, July 2, 2025 at 5:09:07 PM UTC+2 Chris Harrelson wrote:
LGTM1
On Wed, Jun 25, 2025 at 12:46 AM Daniil Sakhapov <sakha...@chromium.org> wrote:
For Blink there are no performance issues as counter value calculation is performed at the same time as for other counters, so it's not really any different from just using counter().
As the real use case for this feature appeared only with Carousel primitives introduction, I don't know of any signals from web devs, but a11y people support it and it's per OpenUI recommendations for Carousels.
ср, 25 июн. 2025 г. в 04:11, Vladimir Levin <vmp...@chromium.org>:
This feature seems to be marked at-risk due to implementation complexity. It isn't clear whether this would mean that to implement this, some features have to be less performant. Do you expect that this feature adds any performance problems?
I also had a question about the lack of Web Developer signals: are there any that you know of?
Thanks! Vlad
On Monday, June 16, 2025 at 10:44:09 AM UTC-4 Daniil Sakhapov wrote:
Contact emails
sakha...@chromium.org
Explainer
None
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-content/#content-property</a>>
Summary
counter() and counters() in alt text of 'content' property is useful to provide more meaningful information to e.g. pseudo elements to improve their accessibility.
Blink component
Blink>CSS
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
It's currently "At risk" <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10387">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10387</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10387">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10387</a>>
/Gecko/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1253">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1253</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1253">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1253</a>>)
/WebKit/: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/515">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/515</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/515">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/515</a>>)
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/css/css-content/parsing/content-counter-valid.html">http://wpt.fyi/css/css-content/parsing/content-counter-valid.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/css/css-content/parsing/content-counter-valid.html">http://wpt.fyi/css/css-content/parsing/content-counter-valid.html</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content.html">http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content.html</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content.html">http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content.html</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content_alt_counter_invalidation.html">http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content_alt_counter_invalidation.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content_alt_counter_invalidation.html">http://wpt.fyi/accname/name/comp_name_from_content_alt_counter_invalidation.html</a>>
Flag name on about://flags
CSSAltCounter
Finch feature name
None
Non-finch justification
None
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/417488055">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/417488055</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/417488055">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/417488055</a>>
Estimated milestones
DevTrial on desktop 138 DevTrial on Android 138
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5185442420621312?gate=5133455599599616">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5185442420621312?gate=5133455599599616</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5185442420621312?gate=5133455599599616">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5185442420621312?gate=5133455599599616</a>>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org">mailto:blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org</a>>. To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAH3Z928W%3D%2BbSPB2nr81kOi%3D24UN2-JxEn6Yt8j5Pqggef18H-w%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAH3Z928W%3D%2BbSPB2nr81kOi%3D24UN2-JxEn6Yt8j5Pqggef18H-w%40mail.gmail.com</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAH3Z928W%3D%2BbSPB2nr81kOi%3D24UN2-JxEn6Yt8j5Pqggef18H-w%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAH3Z928W%3D%2BbSPB2nr81kOi%3D24UN2-JxEn6Yt8j5Pqggef18H-w%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>.
